member.name: T:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.CompressingFilter
member.summary: Base for any HttpFilter that performing compression
member.remarks: When implementing this class, you need to implement a along with a . The latter corresponds to a content coding (see http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec3.html#sec3.5) that your implementation will support.

member.name: T:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter
member.summary: The base of anything you want to latch onto the Filter property of a object.
member.remarks: These are generally used with but you could really use them in other HttpModules. This is a general, write-only stream that writes to some underlying stream. When implementing a real class, you have to override void Write(byte[], int offset, int count). Your work will be performed there.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Subclasses need to call this on contruction to setup the underlying stream
member.param: The stream we're wrapping up in a filter

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Not supported. Throws an exception saying so.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Not supported. Throws an exception saying so.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.Close
member.summary: Closes this Filter and the underlying stream.
member.remarks: If you override, call up to this method in your implementation.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.Flush
member.summary: Fluses this Filter and the underlying stream.
member.remarks: If you override, call up to this method in your implementation.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Not supported.
member.param: The buffer to write into.
The offset on the buffer to write into
The number of bytes to write. Must be less than buffer.Length
member.returns: An int telling you how many bytes were written

member.name: P:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.BaseStream
member.summary: Allow subclasses access to the underlying stream

member.name: P:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.CanRead
member.summary: False. These are write-only streams

member.name: P:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.CanSeek
member.summary: False. These are write-only streams

member.name: P:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.CanWrite
member.summary: True. You can write to the stream. May change if you call Close or Dispose

member.name: P:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.Length
member.summary: Not supported. Throws an exception saying so.

member.name: P:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpOutputFilter.Position
member.summary: Not supported. Throws an exception saying so.

The level of compression to use when compressing the content

member.name: T:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpModule
member.summary: An HttpModule that hooks onto the Response.Filter property of the current request and tries to compress the output, based on what the browser supports

remarks.p: This HttpModule uses classes that inherit from . We already support gzip and deflate (aka zlib), if you'd like to add support for compress (which uses LZW, which is licensed), add in another class that inherits from HttpFilter to do the work.

This module checks the Accept-Encoding HTTP header to determine if the client actually supports any notion of compression. Currently, we support the deflate (zlib) and gzip compression schemes. I chose to not implement compress because it uses lzw which requires a license from Unisys. For more information about the common compression types supported, see http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.11 for details.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpModule.System#Web#IHttpModule#Init(System.Web.HttpApplication)
member.summary: Init the handler and fulfill
member.remarks: This implementation hooks the ReleaseRequestState and PreSendRequestHeaders events to figure out as late as possible if we should install the filter. Previous versions did not do this as well.
member.param: The this handler is working for.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpModule.System#Web#IHttpModule#Dispose
member.summary: Implementation of
member.remarks: Currently empty. Nothing to really do, as I have no member variables.

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpModule.CompressContent(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: EventHandler that gets ahold of the current request context and attempts to compress the output.
member.param: The that is firing this event.
Arguments to the event

member.name: M:blowery.Web.HttpCompress.HttpModule.GetFilterForScheme(System.String[],System.IO.Stream,blowery.Web.HttpCompress.Settings)
member.summary: Get ahold of a for the given encoding scheme. If no encoding scheme can be found, it returns null.
member.remarks: See http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.3 for details on how clients are supposed to construct the Accept-Encoding header. This implementation follows those rules, though we allow the server to override the preference given to different supported algorithms. I'm doing this as I would rather give the server control over the algorithm decision than the client. If the clients send up * as an accepted encoding with highest quality, we use the preferred algorithm as specified in the config file.
